docs.abstract: As the Senate moved forward Tuesday on the reconciliation bill, Republicans proposed many changes.
docs.snippet: As the Senate moved forward Tuesday on the reconciliation bill, Republicans proposed many changes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, put forward a number of amendments Tuesday to the reconciliation bill now being debated on the Senate floor.
docs.abstract: A Republican senator offers some unexpected amendments to the reconciliation bill.
docs.snippet: A Republican senator offers some unexpected amendments to the reconciliation bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: What was that I just said about a cynical Republican Party learning to love the unsustainable aspects of Obamacare instead of paring them back? Here's John Cornyn, sketching out a possible G.O.P. health care agenda for the next few years:
docs.abstract: In which we get a taste of Republican cynicism to come ...
docs.snippet: In which we get a taste of Republican cynicism to come ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House majority leader, Steny Hoyer of Maryland, said Tuesday that he was "disappointed" by some lawmakers' conduct during Sunday night's health care debate, and he urged House leaders to warn their members against inappropriate behavior.
docs.abstract: The House majority leaders said that some Republicans were out of line on Sunday night.
docs.snippet: The House majority leaders said that some Republicans were out of line on Sunday night.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tyler Cowen has a thoughtful post analyzing how the health care bill might evolve. The following part of his argument tracks, to some extent, with the more optimistic of the scenarios I sketched out yesterday:

headline.main: A Dose of Health Care Pessimism

docs.abstract: The hard choices we need to make, but probably won't.
docs.snippet: The hard choices we need to make, but probably won't.

docs.lead_paragraph: "... Generations of conservatives have complained that the so-called mainstream media have been biased against them. Well, get ready, Republicans, for déjà vu all over again. The coverage through November likely will highlight the most extreme attacks on the President and his law and spotlight stories of real Americans whose lives have been improved by access to health care ... The louder Republicans yell, the more they will be characterized and caricatured as sore losers infuriated by the first major delivery of candidate Obama's promise of "change." ... But fighting back against a supposedly hostile press is old hat for the GOP. A far greater challenge will come from a new quarter. Large segments of the American business community are going to present a formidable ally for Obamacare, either with outspoken support or notable silence. From businesses that have been crushed by rising health care costs, to pharmaceutical companies cleverly co-opted by the White House early on in the process, to the doctors' organizations (including the American Medical Association) that endorsed the final product, to, yes, even the vilified insurance companies - none of these entities are going to join the charge to reverse the new reality of U.S. health care, and many will make it clear that they are resigned to or actually in favor of the apparently inevitable conclusion."
docs.abstract: Mark Halperin on the G.O.P.'s uphill fight.
docs.snippet: Mark Halperin on the G.O.P.'s uphill fight.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama signed his health care overhaul - the most sweeping social legislation enacted in decades - into law on Tuesday during a festive, at times raucous, ceremony in the East Room of the White House. Among those who joined him around the desk were 11-year-old Marcelas Owens of Seattle, who became an advocate for health care reform after his mother died without health insurance.

headline.main: History, and Marcelas Owens, Look On

docs.abstract: PICTURES OF THE DAY: President Obama signed his health care overhaul into law as 11-year-old Marcelas Owens of Seattle watched.
docs.snippet: PICTURES OF THE DAY: President Obama signed his health care overhaul into law as 11-year-old Marcelas Owens of Seattle watched.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Bucks team helped answer questions about the health care bill over on the Prescriptions blog. One reader asked whether the bill would extend Cobra eligibility through 2014, when many of the most crucial insurance affordability measures take effect.

headline.main: How the Health Care Bill Affects Cobra

docs.abstract: How the health care bill affects COBRA and the possibility for extended eligibility.
docs.snippet: How the health care bill affects COBRA and the possibility for extended eligibility.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Mr. Obama finished signing the bill, the first hand he shook was that of Marcelas Owens, an 11-year-old who has helped Democrats put a human face on the health care debate by talking about the death of his mother.
docs.abstract: "You have turned the right of every American to have access to decent health care into reality for the first time in American history," Vice President Joseph Biden told President Obama.
docs.snippet: "You have turned the right of every American to have access to decent health care into reality for the first time in American history," Vice President Joseph Biden told President Obama.

docs.lead_paragraph: The South Orange and Maplewood Board of Education voted unanimously last night to approve Superintendent Brian Osborne's proposed budget, just in time to meet today's deadline for all school districts to submit their budgets to the county executive superintendent for approval.

headline.main: SOMA Board of Ed Approves Austere Budget

docs.abstract: SOMA's new budget includes no salary increases for staff or administrators, cutting of non-personnel items and, most controversially, moving school paraprofessionals off the personnel budget and contracting with an agency to supply them to the district.
